content.description:
Very technical arete. Reach the first bolt on the right side of the arete, it's possible to pass on the left (12b, stick clip the second bolt). clear the face for a prone rest! bouldery exit. Superbe arête technique. Rejoindre la première plaquette à droite de l’arête. Il est possible de passer à gauche (12b, stick clipper la 2è plaquette). Sortir la dalle et revenir vers la gauche pour un repos couché! Sortie bloc. Far right

Bien à droite, secteur du Dôme Bolts.

Plaquettes.

Follow the thin crack until it ends on the right side of the "voie d'évitement" and climb straight the slab to the only glue-in that protects the crux. Suivre la mince fissure jusqu'à sa fermeture à droite de ''voie d'évitement'' et grimper la dalle tout droit vers le seul scellement qui protège le crux. Start area of voie d'évitement. Secteur de départ de voie d'évitement. Standard rack + 1 bolt. Equipped anchor. Rack standard + 1 bolt. Relais équipé.

An easy first pitch to warm up, good enough pro placements. The end of the second pitch starts to runout. You can manage to setup a belay on the last tree before the big roof. The slab is R rated (nuts and micro cams). The roof is the crux and have better pro options. No informations about pitch 3. Beautiful climb! From the parking lot, take the biggest path, right to the mailbox. then, first left, first left again. the path should go left for some time.
You should arrive at the start of a big slab, with a big roof upper. Here you are! Trad gear, micros, tricams can help. You can manage to make some belays on trees.

Fissure moins franche passant à droite du petit toit de 1 pied.

Relais sur le bouleau à la vire végétale et attention il faut une corde de 70 m pour le rappel si vous en avez seulement une.

--- 

Less straightforward crack passing to the right of the small 1 foot roof.

Belay on the birch tree at the vegetal ledge and be careful you need a 70 m rope for the rappel if you only have one.



Quatre mètre à droite de Point G.

--- 

Four meters at the right (climber's right) of ''Point G''

trad + anchor on a tree

Fun slab route. Start by going straight up, then traverse left with good foot holds, do a slab dyno and go straight up until you reach a vegetated ledge with a rap station.



Follow a fixe d rope in a small trail that climbs above the regular trail on a large vegetated legde.

about 10 quickdraws + a few small cams/nuts
Monter haut dans le dièdre pour rejoindre la première plaquette sur la face gauche. La voie est courte mais l'escalade est technique. Alternance entre le face et les coins.  Secteur des toits 5 bolts

Large obvious dihedral on the right side of the slab. Often a bit wet.

Gros dièdre évident bordant la droite de la dalle. Souvent mouillé en partie.



Secteur Gruyère


Standard rack + BD#6, fixed anchor.

Rack standard + BD#6, relais fixe.

Basically a very long traverse to the left, all the way on excellent and clean rock, until you reach the top of L'Initiation. Walk off descent.



From the Dome parking, follow the trail and take the left at all forks. When you reach the base of the cliff, follow it to the left until you reach a slab of about 5m followed by a vertical wall (about 1.5 meter high).

Trad, gear belays.

L'itinéraire est très beau et les sections de rocher sont suffisamment longues entre les vires végétales. Les fissures sont sales du au manque de répétition mais, cela n'affecte pas trop la grimpe puisque il y a plusieurs prises en dehors des fissures.

L1 (115 ft) : Suivre la fissure continu sur la majorité de la longueur. Possibilité d'aller rejoindre l'arbre de gauche pour aller faire un premier relais mais, j'ai trouvé plus direct et évident de continuer tout droit et faire un relais sur protections naturelles.

L2 (175 ft) : Continuer de suivre la fissure plus à droite pour rejoindre une grosse vire végétale avec quelques bouleaux. Faire un relais sur les arbres. La fin de la longueur passe sur une dalle à droite d'un dièdre (faisant face à la droite). Attention, plusieurs blocs lousses situés à la fin de ce dièdre.

L3 (150 ft) : Encore, prendre la fissure la plus à droite vers la base d'un pilier superbe et légèrement déversant. Passer à gauche de ce pilier dans la très belle fissure immédiatement à gauche. Relais sur arbre.

Il n'y a aucun relais fixe dans cette voie mise à part des arbres équipé de sangles et maillons rapides bien espacés pour la descente en rappel. (2022) 

Rappel avec 2 cordes de 60 m.

--- 

The route is very nice and the rock sections are long enough between the vegetal ledges. The cracks are dirty due to the lack of repetition but, this doesn't affect the climbing too much since there are several holds outside the cracks.

L1 (115 ft): Follow the continuous crack for the majority of the length. You can join the tree on the left to do a first belay but I found it more direct and obvious to continue straight and do a belay on trad protections.

L2 (175 ft): Continue to follow the crack further to the right to reach a large vegetation ledge with some birch trees. Make a belay on the trees. The end of the pitch is on a slab on the right of a dihedral (facing right). Be careful, several loose boulders at the end of this dihedral.

L3 (150 ft): Again, take the rightmost crack to the base of a beautiful, slightly overhanging pillar. Pass to the left of this pillar in the very nice crack immediately to the left. Belay on a tree.

There are no fixed belays in this route except for trees equipped with well-spaced slings and quick links for rappelling. (2022) 

Abseiling with 2 ropes of 60 m.



Se rendre au bas de ''Point G'' sous un mur noire. Une corde fixe a été aménagé immédiatement à droite pour facilité l'accès à la vire. Au dessus de la dernière vire se trouve une fissure continu sur presque la totalité de la première longueur. 

---

Go to the bottom of "Point G" under a black wall. A fixed rope has been set up immediately to the right for easy access to the pitch. Above the last pitch there is a crack that continues for almost the entire first pitch.

trad gear

Slab. #0.75 cam (or a stick clip) at the start. Dalle. cam #0.75 (ou un stick clip) au départ. Easy to spot the glue in line on the obvious black line.

Il est facile de repérer la voie de scellements sur la ligne noire évidente. Glue-ins, equiped anchor.

Scellements, relais équipé.

The most obvious crack of the sector. Take this crack to a small roof. Climb the ridge slightly to the left (crux) to reach the anchor. La fissure la plus évidente du secteur. Prendre cette fissure jusqu'à un petit toit. Grimper l'arête légèrement à gauche (crux) pour rejoindre le relais. Take the path to reach the bottom of voie d'évitement, continue again towards the patinoire and again along the fixed ropes to the higher area. Be careful, falling is not an option, protect the belayer in case of a fall. Prendre le sentier pour rejoindre le bas de voie d'évitement, continuer encore vers patinoire et encore le long des cordes fixes vers le secteur plus en hauteur. Attention, la chute n'est pas une option, protéger l'assureur en cas de chute. Standard rack + many cams. Equipped anchors. Rack standard + beaucoup de bloqueurs. Relais équipé.

Great route with many options if you want to spice things up on the way. Two 60+m ropes are a must. Don't set belays off the rap rings! Try to use the chain links and leave room for other parties heading up or down the route. Pitch 1 5.5 Climb up the polished steep face with tiny cracks (easier following vegetation on the left) passed the first tree ledge (easier after) up to the belay at the next tree ledge. Pitch 2 5.5 Aim up and follow a diagonal depression towards the left then up again following easier features, traverse diagonally right when approaching the next belay ledge. Pitch 3 5.6 Climb up path of least resistance until you get to a sloping ledge with a little headwall, watch your ankles (rope stretch) as you go up the crack on the left (crux) passed a bolt to a ledge with the belay on the right. Pitch 4 5.5 (V1) Head up to the corner above the belay and make your way along a lower angle slab with a couple interesting bulges up to the belay. V1 traverse right along tiny holds and not so great pro to a very textured black streak, this section is just amazing, passed a bolt and keep heading up the P4 slab. Route is at the far left end of the cliff when you take the main trail.
Rap down the belays, be mindful of other climbers. Tricam and nut heaven, a lot of the cracks are heavily pocketed, you'll find chicken heads and other smaller pockets.
A couple bolts where you need them and belays/raps are bolted.

Voie classique du secteur. Celle-ci suit une fissure mince qui rejoint ensuite trois fissures horizontales. La façade parsemé de trous, tel un fromage gruyère, est emblématique du Dôme. Vue du sol, elle peut paraitre sale et mal protégé, mais ce n'est pas le cas.

An area classic. Gruyère follors a thin crack that leads into three horizontal cracks. The rock face's features, that resemble a Gruyère cheese, are iconic of Dôme climbing. The route can appear dirty and poorly protected from the ground, but it is not the case.



Première voie à la droite de la coulée. Elle est à la gauche du croisant de lune de «Jeux sans frontières» à mi-chemin entre le grand dièdre et la coulée. Prendre le sentier vers la coulée.

First line to the right of the «coulée» stream. To the left of 'Jeux sans frontières'' half moon crescent half way between the dihedral and the choss. Take the trail to la coulée.

Smaller gear. Nuts and tricams. Bolted anchor.

Easy start, a glue-in protects the short crux on the slab, followed by a finger crack. Départ facile, un scellement protège de crux en dalle très court, puis fissure à doigt. From fun noir, move a few meters to the right. Locate the route with a visible glue-in stuck on a small dihedral.

À partir de fun noir, déplacez vous quelques mètres vers la droite. Repérez la voie grace à un scellement visible collé sur un petit dièdre. Standard rack, one glue-in, anchor on top.

Trad, un scellement, relais au top.

Perfectly clean and solid rock.

Start on an easy slab with multiple vertical cracks and continue straight up toward the most obvious vertical crack. The crack eventually widens (crux) but only hand jams are needed.



From the rightmost sector of the Dome (overhanging, clean, white rock, where Astral is), follow the wall toward climber's left for about 30 meters. 

There is a large clean and slabby face with many vertical cracks tending slightly  to the left. In the middle of this face, there is rectangular roof, bounded by the two most obvious cracks. The route follows one of these cracks, the one on the right.


trad gear, up to #2

two glues in at the top for rappel.

This is the first route climbed in Grands-Jardins (1970). A long beautiful line with lots of fun and good rock. With the exception of the intial 5.6 pitch the rest of the route is 5.4 with good protection. Bolted anchors (with rap rings) are found all the way up to the very top. They seem to be set more specifically for rappelling and not always where you want your belay, so prepare to set your own trad anchor on some of the upper pitches. This description follows the way we climbed it, using mostly bolted anchors and shorter pitches when not being able to see each others, which is pretty much each and every pitch. It can also get hard to hear each other at some of the pitches. Experienced climbers can easily stretch and combine pitches. Pitch 1) At the base, surmount the overlap and work your way towards the bolt. Afterwards move right to flatter ground and a dihedral. Climb it (with interesting un-obvious moves) to bolted anchor. Pitch 2) Traverse left till you see a bolt even further left. Ignore it. Climb towards a second bolt above and climb the right leaning ramp/crack till you are above the bolted anchor. Work you way up passing horizontal cracks till next bolted anchor. Pitch 3) Go up through featured and pocketed terrain through an opening in the bushes. Pass a ledge with a tree with an old rappel sling/ring. Continue up on the left till bolted anchor. Pitch 4) Up the slab through opening in bushes passing a bolted anchor to another one not much higher up. Pitch 5) Straight up to the headwall and bolted anchor. You could also go diagonal left and go straight to a bolted anchor on the left side of the headwall, skipping the next traverse-pitch. Pitch 6) Traverse left around 30m (100 feet or so) till you see a diagonal right ramp (more of a crack). Pitch 7) Climb the ramp/crack up/right and over the headwall. You will see some webbing around a rock to the left (presumably a rap station). Continue to small overhanging headwall with a weakness. Build trad anchor just before. You could continue over the overhang to a bolted anchor not much after, but you will have hard time hearing your second. Pitch 8) Surmount the overhang with a perfect left handhold, pass a bolted anchor and continue to the next headwall with a slopy left ramp and a more distinctive right ramp. Build trad anchor at base (big gear). Pitch 9) Go up the right wide ramp with a nice crack on the left. Then continue up to a small ledge among the pocketed wall and horizontals where you can set a trad anchor. Again, if you prefer you can continue to a bolted anchor a little higher, but doing so will be harder to communicate with your second. Pitch 10) Climb the very pocketed wall and small overlap to the top of the cliff and bolted anchor. This is the top of the climb where you can enjoy your lunch and excellent views! Don't try bushwack to the actual summit. Though it looks like there is not much to it, it's a loooong heinous way. Park at the main parking lot for Le Dôme and walk north along the road for 300m (1000') till you see a wooden sign for L'Initiation. This is where the approach trail starts. It's a short 5-10 min hike with some elevation gain to the base. The 5.6 start is just to the left, stepping up an overlap and you will see clean rock with a high bolt. Protection is generally very good with gear everywhere you need it. Lots of horizontal cracks everywhere. .4 and .5 BD cams (and pink/red tricams) are nice. At the top veer left till you see a big cairn. That is the start of the descent trail. It's slighlty faded at some spots in the beginning but generally easy to follow. Just keep going left until it hits a big gully and it gets steeper. The footing can be a little treachearus at times, so be careful and take your time. Towards the end the trail merges into a brook and out on the main road. It comes out 100m or so (a few hundred feet) north of the approach trail.

You can also retreat and rappel at pretty much any point along the route. There are bolted rappel stations along the whole way. You "may" be able to rappel with a 60m rope the whole way down but don't take my word for it.

climbs.name: L'Onglée
climbs.fa: Jean Pierre Cadot & Pierre Desautel, September 1972

content.description:
This route is not meant for the aspiring 5.7 climber, you will often be 20+ ft above your protection, if you find pro, use it because you may not find much higher up. Two 60+m ropes are a must. P1 Climb straight up through the treed ledge P2 Head straight up and follow the trees on the right until you find a vertical seam to a little bushy stance at the top of the treed section (can be combined with P1). P3 Head straight up, aiming to the right side of the bushes (which may fall off the face) followed by a diagonal traverse to the left once you hit a much harder face, set an anchor at the end of the traverse or keep moving up to another good anchor 20m higher. P4 Climb the ovelap on the right of the headwall and go diagonaly righ'ish to the rap station. (can be wet/dirty) Squeezed in variation P2 Traverse a bit left on the ledge and head up passed a small overlap, after about 45-55 meters, look for a nice cracks with decent feet below and left of some shrubs. P3 Head straight up, a bit right of the Granuleuse and find the next belay in a diagonal crack rising towards the left, below the Granuleuse belay and nearly straight under the black head wall. Head up to a cleft between the overhanging headwall. P4 Attack the smaller vertical wall or bypass it from the left, and enjoy the mega textured black wall. Continue Granuleuse's last pitch to the top. Just right of Granuleuse look for the next opening just a bit higher up the trail. Tricam and nut heaven, a lot of the cracks are heavily pocketed, you'll find chicken heads and other smaller pockets.
Anchors are on gear.

climbs.name: La Bibitte
climbs.fa: FA : Émilie Pellerin (2016) Équipé par Benoit Dubois (2014)

content.description:
Unique route at the Dome!
Common start with Astral. After the 4th bolt, cross to the left to tackle the overhanging arete A route that requires power and precision at the same time. Same end as Astral for the last draw.

Route unique en son genre au Dôme! 
Départ commun avec Astral. Après la 4ieme bolts, traverser sur la gauche pour affronter l'arête déversante. Une route qui demande puissance et précision en même temps. Même fin que Astral pour la dernière dégaine.



Secteur des toits

8 bolts

Départ dans Astral jusqu'à la deuxième plaquette pour ensuite traverser dans Côté Obscur. 



Secteur des toits

6 bolts

La voie commence sur une courte dalle qui mène à une mince fissure vers un dièdre un peu plus haut. La protection est mince au départ mais suffisante, la cote PG est nécessaire seulement si on considère que les feuillets au sommet sont possiblement fragile, mise à part cela, la protection est bonne selon moi.

----

The route starts on a short slab that leads to a thin crack to a dihedral a bit higher. The protection is thin at the start but sufficient, the PG rating is only necessary if we consider that the flakes at the top are possibly fragile, apart from that, the protection is good.



The wall at the left of the overhang.


trad gear (no4 is usefull to protect the wide crack at the end) + bolted achor with rap ring.

climbs.name: Le baiser de l'homme araignée
climbs.fa: François Roy, Thomas Ryan, Stéphane Lapierre. 1986.

content.description:
Beautiful overhanging crack, starts as a chimney and finishes into a finger crack. Great pro

La superbe craque déversante débute en cheminée pour finir en fissure à doigts. La protection y est plus qu’excellente.

Trad gear + fixed anchor on top.

climbs.name: Le cormoran
climbs.fa: FA : Julien Bourassa-Moreau (2015) Équipé par Benoit Dubois (2011)

content.description:
Copyright issue, to be updated.



Secteur des toits

bolts

La voie parcourt une série de gros blocs déversant séparé par de bons repos. Très 3D et rempli de bonne prise. Le relais se trouve dans le devers juste avant le toit de Yahaka (5.11c). Possibilité de finir dans Yahaka pour prolongé la voie.

Attention: La plaquette de droite au relais est très rouillée et le goujon est exposé.

-----

The route goes through a series of big overhanging boulders separated by good rests. Very 3D and full of good holds. The belay is in the overhang just before the roof of Yahaka (5.11c). Possibility to finish in Yahaka to extend the route.

Caution: The right bolt at the belay is very rusty and the stud is exposed.



Voie sportive la plus à droite du Dôme.

The last bolted route on the right of the Wall (right).

Bolts

climbs.name: Orage
climbs.fa: inconnu, Équipé puis nettoyer par Claude Gélinas & Marc-André Dussault en 2019

content.description:
From the belay on a little ledge with trees, start in a 10 feet left facing dihedral to a perfect finger crack splitter. At the roof, go left on the arrete or straight in it. Two glue-in achor.



Start in the middle of the wall. 

Start from the rappel station of ''Crazy Carpet''

It is possible to reach that station from the first pitch of ''Patinoire''

Standard rack

Typical Dôme route, well protected. P1 5.6, Follow the crack, ends at the ledge with a pine. P2 5.7, Keep following the cracks, avoid a large flake by the left. P3 5.8, Head slightly right from the belay and join the next diagonal crack heading left. Possible to link-up pitch 1 & 2. ------------------------------------ Style typique du Dôme, bien protégée. L1 5.6: Suivre la fissure qui fini à une épinette sur la vire. L2 5.7: Continuez dans les fissures pour un autre pitch, éviter un gros feuillet par la gauche. L3 5.8: Légèrement en diagonal vers la droite, puis vers la gauche. Possible de joindre les longueurs 1 & 2. Head up the treed and soil hill, head up until you find yourself at the last obvious diagonal crack.

Monter sur la vire avec de la terre, continuer jusqu'à la dernière fissure évidente en oblique vers la gauche. Vous y êtes. Deux relais équipés. Trad.

A slightly slabby very thin finger crack. Get your best smearing/small edges shoes and get ready to jam/crimp on small pods & edges. It's not physically super hard but it fells quite delicate at times.

The lower section is 10b (guidebook). Once the angle lessens, you have a choice: you can keep going up on the slab on spaced out & trickier gear (guidebook says 5.7, the actual route). You can arrange a traverse to the left and & rejoin the end of Gaston Boston (also 5.7, but better gear).

Could use a bit of love (brushing and/or more traffic).



Need to go to the climber's right of Voie d'Évitement. The trail will go down & away from the wall, and then back up steeply in a kind of 4th class bushwack. Just to the left of it will be the obvious hand crack of Gaston Boston (5.7). Perdu dans l'Espace is the thinner crack to the left.

Small cams & perhaps a few small nuts for the 10b part. Once you traverse on Gaston Boston a few larger cams. Unsure about the upper slab if going straight.

Une mince fissure traverse un mur verticale. Suivre la fissure qui s'élargie pour rétrécir plus haut.

Relais sur le bouleau à la première vire végétalisée et attention il faut une corde de 70 m pour le rappel si vous en avez seulement une.

---

A thin crack crosses a vertical wall. Follow the crack as it widens and narrows higher up.

Belay on the birch tree at the first vegetated ledge and beware you need a 70 m rope for the rappel if you have only one.



Dans un mur noir au début de la vire pour se rendre au relais de ''Terasse Alino'' et ''La petite école''

---

In a black wall at the beginning of the turn to go to the relay of ''Terasse Alino'' and ''La petite école

trad + sangle & anneau de rappel sur l'arbre

P1 5.10a 50m
Tandis que "La voie de rappel" vire à gauche, pour Temps de cure il faut plutôt suivre une bande noire en ligne droite (protection possible d'un côté et de l'autre de cette bande noire, mais plus rare sur la bande noire elle-même). Un premier scellement sera bientôt visible juste avant la première ligne d'arbres (un passage étroit est dégagé dans cette ligne d'arbres). Le crux 10a se situe sur un slab raide juste au-dessus. Il bien protégé par deux autres scellements. 

P2 5.9 PG13/R 50m
La deuxième longueur s'élève en ligne presque droite au-dessus du premier relais. On voit bien un premier tout petit move surplombant à-travers les branches taillées. C'est PG13/R, il faut un jeu double de petit gear et de l'imagination. Des tricams sont utiles. Feuillets très fragiles en fin de longueur. Relais comme pour la deuxième longueur de "Tache blanche".

P3 5.8 30m
Au lieu d'aller à droite comme "Tache blanche", il faut plutôt marcher sur le gros bloc à gauche du relais jusqu'à ce que de bonnes prises se présentent et permettent de s'élever. On gagne la vire de terre de "Tache blanche" à gauche du troisième relais de cette dernière. Plus à gauche encore sur la vire de terre il y a un autre relais. 

P4 5.7 70m
La quatrième longueur fait 70m (cordes doubles de 60 mètres avec beaucoup d'élasticité ou encore 70m pour le rappel), mais c'est aussi possible de s'arrêter sur un arbre en chemin. Rester à gauche quand le mur se redresse à environ 35m du relais. Les fissures de gauche sont délicieuses et y a plein de grosses prises, même si ça parait très/trop vertical. À droite, ça a l'air plus facile, mais c'est moins plaisant. Le relais est 15m plus haut que la talle d'arbres au-dessus du ressaut vertical.



Départ pas plus d'un mètre à droite de "La voie de rappel". 

Rack double, surtout les petits cams. Quelques bolts dans le premier pitch.

climbs.name: Tâche Blanche
climbs.fa: Régis Richard, Jacques Lamontagne et F.X. Garneau (1975)

content.description:
Three (3) magnificent technical pitches of slab. P1 5.10c 55m (4 bolts + 2 piton) Reestablish yourself up a narrow ramp and follow it on the right for a couple a feet. Place pros, then head straight up for the pitons and bolts. Rétablissez vous sur la rampe mince et la suivre pour quelques pieds.  Protégez puis suivez les pitons et bolts jusqu'au relais. P2 5.10a 36m (3 bolts) Traverse left on the ramp and follow the bolts until you hit the horizontal crack. Follow the crack to your left to the anchor. Suivez les bolts vers la gauche jusqu’à la fissure horizontale jusqu’à l'ancrage. P3 5.10b 50m (5 bolts) Traverse right, clip two (2) bolts, then head straight up passing a good horizontal and some features. Traversez vers la droite passé 2 bolts puis allez tout droit (vers le haut) passé une bonne fissure horizontale et quelques elements jusqu'au relais sur la vire. Descent Rappel P3 and do two (2) more rappels straight down Trois (3) rappels corde double directement vers le bas. From the parking lot take the trail that leads to the lodge "Chalet du Dôme". At the fork, go right and once you're behind the lodge find a path that goes left in the direction of the cliff.
The route starts pretty much where the approach trail hits the cliff on an impressive slab. You start on a ledge 5m above the trail. Du stationement prenez les directions du chalet du Dome, une fois au chalet, passez le par la droite et suivez le sentier jusqu’à la paroi.
La voie débute juste en face du sentier sur une vire 5m plus haut. Up to Camalot #2 plus a selection of nuts. There are bolts and fixed anchors on the route.
--
Jusqu'au Camalot #2 et des bicoins. il y a des bolts, pitons et bien sur les ancrage sont boltés.

Une dalle remplie de petits trous qui rejoint le deuxième relais de Granuleuse. Le départ est propre et passe par un petit toit traversé d'une fissure à doigts verticale. La voie est une bonne alternative de départ de granuleuse après la pluie puisqu'elle est souvent sèche au contraire des autres départ du secteur. La longueur est environ 65 mètres donc elle peut être séparer en deux pour limiter le tirage et ne pas faire du simul mais, ça passe en une seule. Les options de relais ne sont pas abondantes.

---

A slab filled with small holes that goes to the second belay of Granuleuse. The start is clean and goes through a small roof with a vertical finger crack. The route is a good alternative to the start of Granuleuse after the rain since it is often dry unlike the other starts in the area. The length is about 65 meters so it can be split in two to limit the drag and to not make simul at the end but it can be done in one pitch. Belay on gears options are not abundant.  

 



15 meters left of the start of Granuleuse.

trad gear

P1 5.6 40m Follow the left leaning crack to the ledge above. Traverse the ledge to the birch tree and head up to the fixed anchor. One of the nicest pitch on the cliff. Suivez la fissure à gauche jusqu'à la vire puis traversez à droite. Au Boulot, montez tout droit jusqu'à l'ancrage fixe. P2 5.7 40m Stick to the diagonal cracks heading left to a good ledge under a small roof. Continuez la fissure diagonal passé un petit renflemment jusqu'à la plateforme sous un toit. P3, 5.5 40m PG13 More broken up diagonal cracks on seemingly easier grounds but with less pro. Once you get to a ledge with large blocks, go left to Tache Blanche's anchor/rap. Restez toujours dans ces fissures cassées, la protection n'est pas superbe, mais la grimpe n'est pas trop difficile. Arrivé à la vire, traversez les blocs à gauche jusqu'à l'ancrage de Tache Blanche. P4 5.8 62m From the anchor (same as Tache blanche), climb up a slab with holes first tending to the left, then straight ahead. When it gets steeper, it's more fun to go looking for the cracks on the left and even if it looks harder, in fact it's 5.7, good pro, good holds. Traverse a mini tree line (possible intermediate anchor) to find a system of diagonal cracks. The anchor will appear above, the last meters you have to climb in a straight line on a nice rock. Du relais (le même que Tâche blanche), on monte une dalle à trous d'abord en tendant à gauche, puis tout droit. Quand ça se redresse, c'est plus le fun d'aller chercher les fissures à gauche et même si ça a l'air plus dur, en fait c'est 5.7, bonne pro, bonnes prises. On traverse une mini talle d'arbres (possibilité de relais) pour récupérer un système de fissures diagonales. Le relais va apparaitre au-dessus, les derniers mètres il faut les grimper en ligne droite sur du beau rocher. From the trail-head, head left a bit and up onto the thin ledge at the base of the wall, then cross the open area on climber's right passed the 5.11 bolted route to a raised platform, take off on the obvious crack on the left.
Rappel down Tache Blanche.

Du sentier, monter jusqu'au pied du mur un peu a votre gauche puis traversez la clairière sure la petite vire, passé la voie sportive jusqu’à un petite terrasse. la voie débute dans la fissure a gauche.
Rappel sur la Tache Blanche. Double rack to #1 one #2, lots o nuts (offsets not so much) and tricams.

climbs.name: Voie de Rappel
climbs.fa: Regis Richard, Jacques LaMontange & F.X. Garneau 1975

content.description:
A nice route that has long cracks and features some exciting pocketed slab. P1: 5.6 45m, Climb up some easily to get into a nice vertical finger/hand crack. follow this to a break in the trees. Belay on the treed ledge at 2 bolts. P2: 5.7 55m, Directly over the belay is a small roof with a wide crack. Slap in a cam [3" cam OK 4" is better] and tackle the pocketed face. Once at a small ledge tackle yet another pocketed face t another ledge. Clip the rusty bolt and climb up to get into a sweet diagonal crack. Enjoy he left leaning crack until you spot a bolted belay at a nice clean ledge. P3: 5.6 50m, Continue in the left leaning crack to a roof and pass it on the left. Now climb on a right rising line, staying close to the right leaning corner/roof features. Aim for the right end of a patch of trees. Once almost at the end you spy a set of belay bolts up on the treed ledge. Descent: R1 35m, Rap to that patch of trees below you. Decide whether you want to pass this island on trees on the right or left. the anchor is about 10m below these trees. R2 & R3 just reverse the route. Nuts and lots of Tricams up to blue and double pink & red. Cams 1-2" plus 4".
ALL Belays are bolted. Once the approach trail meets the cliff, head left along the base. Just before a sharp dip in the trail, you'll spot a nice vertical crack ending at a treed ledge.

Sweet crack trending left, the start is a bit tricky but the route is brilliant and well protected. P1 5.7, 50m head to the diagonal finger/hand crack, belay at a ledge. P2 5.9, 55m Head up the ledge above, traverse left and meetup with the left leaning diagonal crack system. you have a pin/fixed nut below the roof if you feel like having an intermediate belay (add more gear and it's 5.7 up to there). Follow the left facing corner up to the roof, pull through it. keep heading up and cross another bail anchor of sling+ring. Head up through the cleft in the wall, this last portion before the anchor is committing and not obvious to protect but once you figure it out it's a breeze. The route used to go on for another pitch or two but the rock up there is extremely unstable and should be avoided. Head right from the approach trail, pass a couple clearing and spot a large left facing corner (Le Diédral), to its left an obvious left trending vertical crack! Double rack, some bolted belay/rap. From the top of the second pitch rappel STRAIGHT down to the ledge, eventually an anchor may be placed there to continue, pull your ropes straight down from there.
Traverse climbers right to the gap in the trees you came up, do a small rap to the end of pitch 1 belay station and head down.

Rappelling on an angle from the top to the P1 belay is a sure way to get your rope(s) stuck! beware.

First crack on the right of ''dérobade''. Right side of the arrete.

Première fissure à droite de ''dérobade''. Du coté droit de l'arrête.



Well-rounded route with a lot of techniques involves. The end is in the same crak as ''derobade''. Somes fragile holds at the top.

Voie très varié en terme de mouvement. La fin de la voie se fait dans la fissure supérieure de ''dérobade''. Quelques prises instables en haut.


Standard rack + Alpine draws. Rappel bolts.

Rack standard + longues sangles. Relais équipé

Start in a big right facing dihedral to a short overhanging crack. From the ledge, choose one of the crack to gain the achor. Both are dirty and difficult to protect. Some of the crimps look easy to break off.



Located in the rightmost sector of the Dome.

The rock there is white, clean and very compact.

Starts in the right-facing dihedral just left of "Le baise de l'homme araignee". 

trad gear + anchor

The Dôme being just outside the SEPAQ, you are not required to purchase a day permit to climb it but should pay the daily fee to La Traversé de Charlevoix at la ZEC des Martres 2km north of the Dome, they are the one maintaining the trails. 
 All routes require trad gear and are mostly multi-pitch up to 200m long, not all belays are bolted such as L'Onglée which leaves the climber the choice of path and belay locations. 
 The left and center side of the cliff is mostly a slab affair while the right end (les Toits) has quite a few spicy routes. 
  
 Generally a small set of nuts,a set of tricams (or two) from N0.25(black) to N2(blue), double cams to 0.4 to 1", single C3 #0 to #2, single 2" & 3" will give you more than enough choice. 
  
 Bring double 60m ropes, many belay/raps are a stretch using two 50m ropes. 
 ---------- 
 Le Dôme est juste à l'extérieur de la SEPAQ alors il n'est pas nécessaire d'y payer l'accès mais le sentier est aménagé par La Traversé de Charlevoix qui demande un droit journalier qui doit être payé a la ZEC des Martres 2km au nord du stationnement du Dôme. 
 Toutes les voies sont traditionelles ou mixtes, multi-longueurs et jusqu'à 200m de long et les relais ne sont pas tous équipés comme L'Onglée qui laisse le choix au leader la ligne et les relais. 
 La gauche et le centre du Dôme se caractérise par des voies dalleuses tandis qu'à la droite (les toits) à plusieurs voies sur lesquelles se faire les dents. 
  
 Généralement un petit set de coinceurs, un set (ou deux) de tricams du 0.25(noir) au 2(bleu), mécaniques en double de 0.4 à 1", C3 en simple de #0 à #2, simple 2" & 3" vous donnera pas mal de choix. 
  
 Amenez vos cordes doubles! ou grimpez avec deux cordes de 60m chaques car plusieurs relais et rappels sont très étirés avec des 50m... 
  
 Guidebooks: 
 Le Guide Québécois de l'Escalade par Yannick Girard and Stéphane Plamondon 
  
 Show up at the Trad Pow Wow and get the new "work in progress" topo.
